title: NHS worker slapped with two parking fines while receiving emergency surgery
text:

A NHS worker who needed emergency surgery at the hospital where she works was slapped with two parking fines while under the knife.

Claire Maloney fell ill during a late shift at Medway Maritime Hospital in Kent where she has worked as an admin clerk since September.

The 23-year-old was rushed into surgery.

When she emerged four days later she discovered two parking tickets worth £120 stuck to her car windscreen.

The penalty notice, issued by firm First Parking which manages the hospital's car parks, penalised Claire for parking in the dedicated staff zone 'without clearly displaying a valid permit'.

(Image: SWNS)

Because she only started working at the hospital in September, Claire's parking permit had not arrived by the time she was whisked into the operating theatre.

On the advice of her managers, she had resorted to placing a note in her car window giving contact details for the emergency desk, her phone number and explaining her predicament.

Claire, of Gillingham, Kent, said: "I did that for about two weeks and had no problems.

"But I was unexpectedly admitted for surgery when I was on shift.

"When I was discharged four days later I came back to two fines."

She claims she was never contacted about the tickets when she was recovering on the ward from a uterus infection.

(Image: SWNS)

She has since launched an appeal against the fines.

Claire added: "I read on the staff intranet that they wouldn't be sending tickets to people while they were sorting this new permit.

"Sometimes I finish at midnight and I can't afford to pay for the visitor car park because it's £8 per shift."

Claire's case comes amidst widespread public outcry about NHS staff being charged for parking at the hospitals where they work.

She argued the charges should be scrapped because they "penalise" health workers.

(Image: Getty Images)

"It doesn't seem very fair because you want to be there to help people," she said.

"There's so many people that struggle with how it's being dealt with. They feel like they're not really going to be heard.

"I do understand the NHS need to get their funding from somewhere, but I don't think that charging staff is really the answer."

Medway NHS Trust has launched a new parking system at the hospital which has led to a two month delay for permits to arrive.

The costs are then deducted from their monthly pay packet.

There is also a park and ride scheme for staff, which Claire says she can't use because the last bus runs before she's finished a late shift.

(Image: David Anstiss /Geograph)

Gary Lupton, Executive Director of Estates and Facilities, said: “We recently reviewed our staff car parking arrangements to allow us to better utilise our parking provision at the hospital and create a fairer system for all staff.

“The new on-site parking eligibility criteria was created jointly by our staff and takes into account a number of factors, including the distance between staff members’ home and the hospital.

"Obviously many of our staff work unsociable hours so parking permit options include night only permits which start from 4pm until 8am the following morning and weekend permits.

"The distance criteria does not apply to these applications. New staff members who apply for a permit are informed that the process can take up to four weeks and are offered a space at our offsite parking facility while their application is being processed.

“The new parking permits came into effect in August and we had a settling in period where enforcement measures were not issued to staff who parked without valid permits.

"However, due to the large numbers of staff and some local residents who continued to park on site without permits, last week we introduced enforcement measures to enable staff with valid permits to be able to park onsite.

"This move was supported by staff who are paying for permits but unable to park due to non-compliant parking and the date of when these measures would begin was communicated widely across the Trust.

"In this particular case, we have cancelled the parking tickets that the staff member received.”
description: Claire Maloney was fined £120 while she was under the knife at Medway Maritime Hospital in Kent
